Therefore, the function is correct. So in Fortran, the function can take mid, the array, and the original k, compute the sum, and return whether (k - sum) >=0. So in Fortran, the function would be something like:

FUNCTION NEI(mid, logs, n, k) RESULT(ok)
  INTEGER, INTENT(IN) :: mid, logs(n), k
  INTEGER :: i, sum_total
  sum_total = 0
  DO i = 1, n
    sum_total = sum_total + ( (logs(i) + mid -1) / mid ) -1 END DO
  ok = (k - sum_total) > =0
END FUNCTION

Wait, but in Fortran, integer division is done with /, but in Java, it's integer division as well. So (log + mid -1)/mid is the ceiling of log/mid.

children.text:
Since the first part's array has n elements, which is read first, we can read n first, then allocate the array. But in Fortran, arrays can be declared with a size, but if the size is not known at compile time, we can use an allocatable array. So the code outline would be:

PROGRAM Combined

  IMPLICIT NONE

  INTEGER :: n, k, i, min_val, max_val, mid, sum_total, ans

  INTEGER, ALLOCATABLE :: logs(:)

  ! Read input for first part

  READ(*,*) n, k

  ALLOCATE( logs(n) )

  READ(*,*) (logs(i), i=1,n)

  ! Compute first part's result (min_val)

  min_val = 1

  max_val = 1000000000 + 1000  ! 1e9 + 1000

  DO WHILE (min_val < max_val)

    mid = (min_val + max_val) / 2

    IF ( NEI(mid, logs, n, k) ) THEN

      max_val = mid

    ELSE

      min_val = mid + 1

    END IF

  END DO

  !
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Now, min_val is the result of first part. Use it as n for second part.

  ans = 0

  DO i = 1, min_val

    INTEGER :: q = min_val / i

    ans = ans + i * q * (q +1) / 2

  END DO

  WRITE(*,*) ans

  DEALLOCATE(logs)

CONTAINS

  LOGICAL FUNCTION NEI(mid, logs, n, k)

    INTEGER, INTENT(IN) : : mid, logs(n), k

    INTEGER :: i, total

    total = 0

    DO i = 1, n

      total = total + ( (logs(i) + mid -1) / mid ) -1

    END DO

    NEI = (k - total) >= 0
children.label: code_analysis

So the code outline would be:

PROGRAM Combined

  IMPLICIT NONE

  INTEGER :: n, k, i, min_val, max_val, mid, sum_total, ans

  INTEGER, ALLOCATABLE :: logs(:)

  ! Read input for first part

  READ(*,*) n, k

  ALLOCATE( logs(n) )

  READ(*,*) (logs(i), i=1,n)

  ! Compute first part's result (min_val)

  min_val = 1

  max_val = 1000000000 + 1000  ! 1e9 + 1000

  DO WHILE (min_val < max_val)

    mid = (min_val + max_val) / 2

    IF ( NEI(mid, logs, n, k) ) THEN

      max_val = mid

    ELSE

      min_val = mid + 1

    END IF

  END DO

  ! Now, min_val is the result of first part. Use it as n for second part.

  ans = 0

  DO i = 1, min_val

    INTEGER :: q = min_val / i

    ans = ans + i * q * (q +1) / 2

  END DO

  WRITE(*,*) ans

  DEALLOCATE(logs)

CONTAINS

  LOGICAL FUNCTION NEI(mid, logs, n, k)

    INTEGER, INTENT(IN) :: mid, logs(n), k

    INTEGER :: i, total

    total = 0

    DO i = 1, n

      total = total + ( (logs(i) + mid -1) / mid ) -1

    END DO

    NEI = (k - total) >= 0

  END FUNCTION NEI

END PROGRAM Combined
